Job hunting in 2025 be like:

Apply.
Wait.
Get ghosted.
Reapply to the same job because they reposted it again.
Still ghosted.
Attend 6 rounds of interviews.
Solve a business case.
Design a product roadmap.
Fix the company’s entire strategy.
Only to hear:
“We went ahead with another candidate.”
And my personal favorite:
“We’ll get back to you soon.”
(They never do.)

Dear companies,
We don’t want coffee at your fancy office.
We just want clarity.
A yes or a no.

Not an existential crisis.

To all job seekers reading this -
You’re not lazy.
You’re not unskilled.
You’re not the problem.

You’re just stuck in a broken system where “hiring pipeline” matters more than human dignity.

So no -
You’re not overreacting.
You’re just exhausted from proving your worth to people who never intended to hire.

Let’s support each other.

Dear recruiters,

It's already a tough job market.

Please don’t make it worse by posting ghost jobs.

You post a job.
We apply.
We prepare.
We wait.
We follow up.

But deep down, we already know...

That role never existed.
That position was never going to be filled.
It was just posted for 'pipeline building' or to show 'growth activity.'

And yet, we still apply.

Because we’re hopeful.
Because we’re desperate.
Because we believe maybe—just maybe—this one will work out.

After applying for 100+ jobs and hearing nothing back, we don’t just lose time.

We lose confidence.
We lose self-worth.
We start believing we are not enough.

Please remember:
For you, it might just be a 'job listing.'
But for us, it’s our future.

Be kind.
Be honest.
And please… only post if you’re actually hiring.

Here are some numbers -

📌 According to a 2024 Greenhouse survey, over 68% of job seekers believe they’ve applied to roles that were never actually open.

📌 A ResumeBuilder report found that 1 in 5 companies admit to posting jobs they don’t intend to fill — just to look like they’re growing or to gather ‘future candidates.’

📌 Nearly 52% of job seekers say ghost jobs hurt their mental health, and 61% say it led them to take a break from job hunting altogether.

We’re in the middle of mass layoffs, hiring freezes, and budget cuts.

Every application we send feels like a shot in the dark.

We spend hours tailoring our resumes.
Writing custom cover letters.
Preparing for interviews that never happen.

And even after applying to 100+ roles, the inbox stays silent.

Some do it to look like the company is growing.
Some do it just to ‘build a pipeline.’
Some even forget to take the job post down after internal hiring is done.

But for us — the job seekers — this isn’t a game.

It's our future.

We’re not applying just to stay busy.

We're applying because we’ve rent to pay.
Loans to repay.
Families to support.
Mental battles to fight — silently.

Every fake job post wastes our time, energy, and emotional bandwidth.

It’s exhausting to keep giving your 100% to a system that barely gives 1% back.
And when you do this over and over, day after day…

You stop feeling human.
You start feeling invisible.

So, please — post jobs only if you genuinely plan to hire.
Don’t play with our hopes.
Don’t treat job seekers like data points.

The market is already brutal.
Don’t make it worse with empty promises.

You won’t believe what happened when I taught a 'chaiwala' SQL.
I gave him a free YouTube playlist.
He finished it in 15 days.

Then built a dashboard for his tea stall.
Now he tracks peak hours, top-selling items, and even tips.

He doesn’t have a degree.
He has discipline.

Degrees help.
But curiosity? It changes lives.

Never underestimate the power of free resources - and the will to learn.
Never underestimate me, I can write good fictional stories.

I shared the heartbreaking news of innocent Hindus being shot in Kashmir.

They weren’t doing anything wrong.
They were just… living.
Walking. Laughing. Breathing.
Enjoying a moment in their own country.

And now, they’re gone.

And when I spoke about it - out of pain, not anger -

This is what people said -
'You’re supporting the attackers.'
'You’re sympathizing with terrorists.'
'You’re defending them.'
'I have an agenda.'

No. I don’t.
I am against this violence.
Against the hate. Against the bloodshed.

I am angry. And I have every right to be.
Because these terrorists, these monsters, they are the true enemy.

Not the innocent civilians. Not the people who want peace.
But the cowards who hide behind the guise of religion to murder innocent souls.

This is about humanity.
This is about life.
This is about justice.

Those who did this must be held accountable.
The punishment should be severe.
There’s no room for mercy when innocent lives are taken so ruthlessly.

Those who did this are not humans in my eyes.
They are monsters.
They ended lives, shattered families, and scarred the soul of this country.
There is no defense for what they did.

But what I did say… is that this is not about religion.

Because I genuinely believed we all had the right to feel safe in our own land.

To walk freely. To sit at a tea stall. To smile at strangers.

Without the fear of being gunned down for simply existing.

Because I believe with all my heart -
No one, no matter their faith -
 - Hindu, Muslim, Christian, Sikh -

No one, no matter their mother tongue-
-Kannada, Tamil, Hindi, Punjabi, etc -

No *Indian citizen* should ever fear being shot while enjoying a vacation in their own country.

Not for the language they speak.
Not for the name they carry.
Not for the God they pray to.

Isn’t that the most basic expectation we have from our country?

That we can walk freely. Smile freely.
That we can travel with our families and not wonder if we’ll make it home alive?

This is about basic humanity.

What I am against… is hate.
What I am shattered by… is violence in the name of faith.

People using religion to justify murder - that’s the real evil.

Then chanting 'Bismillah' after killing them (It means 'in the name of God')

I didn’t write this post to divide.

Please don’t use this moment to spread hate.
Please don’t comment just to argue or divide.

I wrote it because I’m grieving. Because I’m afraid.

Because this isn’t you vs me.
This should be all of us vs hate. All of us vs violence.

We deserve to live.
We deserve to feel safe.
We deserve to be human - without fear.

Kashmir is one of the most beautiful place - we call it the 'Heaven' and we all should be able to walk freely there!

I had a conversation with my mother 1 month back to plan a solo trip there and she completely said NO, now I understand her pov.

This was planned because Kashmir was healing.
Hope was returning.

That’s all I wanted to say.
That’s all my heart could take today.

𝗜𝗳 𝘆𝗼𝘂'𝗿𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝘆𝗼𝘂𝗿 𝟭𝘀𝘁 𝗼𝗿 𝟮𝗻𝗱 𝘆𝗲𝗮𝗿 𝗼𝗳 𝗦𝗼𝗳𝘁𝘄𝗮𝗿𝗲 𝗘𝗻𝗴𝗶𝗻𝗲𝗲𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴... 𝘀𝘁𝗼𝗽 𝗺𝗮𝗸𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝘀𝗲 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗸𝗲𝘀.

Because these years? They shape your entire future.

𝗟𝗲𝘁’𝘀 𝗯𝗿𝗲𝗮𝗸 𝗶𝘁 𝗱𝗼𝘄𝗻 👇


𝟭. 𝗪𝗲𝗮𝗸 𝗚𝗿𝗶𝗽 𝗼𝗻 𝗙𝘂𝗻𝗱𝗮𝗺𝗲𝗻𝘁𝗮𝗹𝘀
You can't code your way through AI prompts forever.
If writing a simple algorithm feels impossible without ChatGPT, 𝘁𝗵𝗮𝘁’𝘀 𝗮 𝗿𝗲𝗱 𝗳𝗹𝗮𝗴.
You need to master the core:
-Programming Fundamentals
-OOP
-DSA
-DBMS
-FIT
These are not ‘just courses.’ They’re survival kits for your future.


𝟮. 𝗜𝗴𝗻𝗼𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗦𝗼𝗳𝘁 𝗦𝗸𝗶𝗹𝗹𝘀
You know the code. But can you explain it?
Most students avoid communication, teamwork, and leadership , thinking it’s secondary.
It’s not.
If you can’t present your ideas, collaborate in a team, or speak without fear of judgment, your growth is already limited.


𝟯. 𝗖𝗵𝗮𝘀𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗘𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆 𝗦𝗵𝗶𝗻𝘆 𝗧𝗿𝗲𝗻𝗱
New framework? Jump. New library? Jump again.
This cycle never ends — and teaches you nothing.
Before learning anything new, ask:
Why am I learning this?
If you can't answer that, you're just collecting unfinished courses.
Pick one. Master it. Build with it.


𝟰. 𝗖𝗚𝗣𝗔 𝘃𝘀 𝗦𝗸𝗶𝗹𝗹𝘀 — 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗮 𝗕𝗮𝘁𝘁𝗹𝗲
Some students only chase grades. Others only chase skills.
You need both.
CGPA builds credibility. Skills build opportunity.
Don’t choose between them.
Learn how to manage both. Your future self will thank you.


𝟱. 𝗡𝗼𝘁 𝗔𝗰𝘁𝗶𝘃𝗲 𝗼𝗻 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝗳𝗲𝘀𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻𝗮𝗹 𝗣𝗹𝗮𝘁𝗳𝗼𝗿𝗺𝘀
If no one knows what you’re building , you’ll be forgotten.
Show up.
Share what you’re learning.
Post your wins.
Ask questions.
Connect with mentors.
You don’t have to be loud. You just have to be visible.

The only person that you need to impress is the one in the mirror.

There will always be people who doubt you, criticize you, or try to pull you down.

But here’s the truth: the loudest voice in your life should be *yours*.

If you’re right in your eyes, it doesn’t matter what people think of you.

Stop waiting for applause. Stop looking for approval. *Work on yourself, every single day.*

Even when you’re tired.
Even when it feels pointless.
Even when you feel like the world is ahead of you.

Because greatness isn’t about being the best—it’s about being better than the person you were yesterday.

*Comparison is the thief of joy.*

You’re not in a race with anyone. Everyone has their own timeline, their own struggles, and their own triumphs. Focus on showing up for yourself.

💡 *Here’s the secret to growth:*

1️⃣ Take small steps every day. Consistency beats motivation.

2️⃣ Learn something new every day. Knowledge compounds.

3️⃣ Be kind to yourself. You’re a work in progress, and that’s beautiful.

Do not compare your chapter 1 to someone else’s chapter 20.

*Just show up.*

Some days will be tough. Some days you’ll feel like quitting. But remember: each day you invest in yourself is a brick in the foundation of your future.

One step at a time. One day at a time. *You’ve got this.*

LinkedIn hides the good jobs behind basic search.
Use Boolean magic to unlock them. 🧙‍♂️💼

You’re searching 'Product Manager' on LinkedIn and wondering:

“Why do I keep seeing the same 10 jobs everyone else sees?”
“Where are the remote roles?”
“Why do I never get called back?”

Because you’re using LinkedIn like 90% of people.

But the top 1%?
They use Boolean Search.

Welcome to the Episode 2 of LinkedIn Hacks for getting a job with tricks that actually work :)

And here’s the exact formula they use to find hidden jobs 👇

- Try this in your LinkedIn Jobs search bar:

('Product Manager' OR 'Product Owner') AND ('Remote' OR 'WFH') AND ('2025')

🛠️ Then, apply this filter:

➡️ Posted in the past 24 hours

💥 What you get:

Fresh jobs 

Remote roles across titles

Companies planning for 2025 hires

Higher chances of getting noticed

Most people search:
❌ Product Manager
✅ But Boolean lets you search for Product Manager OR Product Owner

❌ “Remote jobs”
✅ Boolean lets you find jobs with Remote OR WFH in title or description.

It’s like switching from candlelight to a telescope.

Want more Boolean strings?

Here’s a bonus for Tech + Remote + Hiring Now:
('Software Engineer' OR 'Backend Developer') AND ('Remote') AND ('Hiring') AND ('2025')

Or for Design folks:
('UI Designer' OR 'UX Designer') AND ('Remote') AND ('Immediate joiner')

🧠 Most people don’t get rejected because they’re not qualified.
They just don’t know how to search.

If this blew your mind, comment 🔍 and I’ll share more job hacks that even recruiters don’t talk about.

I was diagnosed with 'depression' a few months back and I am here to talk about it.

I have been taking prescribed anti-depressants too.

Writing this post is hard? 
Yes.

I know that some people aren't supportive and will say that I am doing this for attention - have been there already.

Openly discussing mental health is crucial because it promotes awareness and normalizes mental health as a part of overall well-being. 

Whenever I needed a day off, I used sick leave and I think it’s understandable to use mental health days under sick leave, especially if there’s a concern about societal shyness or stigma. 

No one really talks about it. Right?

However, fostering open conversations can gradually shift perceptions and create a more accepting environment.

Here are some reasons why talking about mental health matters:

Reduces Stigma: 

Open discussions can help dispel myths and reduce the stigma associated with mental health issues, making it easier for individuals to seek support without fear of judgment.

Encourages Help-Seeking: 

When mental health is openly talked about, it can encourage others to seek help early, which can lead to better outcomes.

Improves Support in Workplaces:

 If employers are aware of the importance of mental health, they may be more likely to implement supportive policies and resources.


Promotes Empathy and Understanding: 

Sharing experiences can foster empathy among peers, leading to stronger, more supportive relationships.

Recognizes Mental Health as a Priority: 

Mental health is just as important as physical health, and acknowledging this can ensure that individuals prioritize their mental well-being.

Talking about our mental health is really important, just like talking about a cold or a headache. 

When we're open about needing a break because we're feeling stressed or down, it helps everyone understand that it's okay to have these feelings. 

It's like saying, 'Hey, I'm not feeling great today, and I need some time to feel better.'

When we hide our mental health days as just 'sick leave,' we miss the chance to show that our minds need care too. 

But when we're honest about it, we help make it normal to talk about mental health. 

This can make more people feel okay about taking a break when they need it, without feeling shy or worried about what others will think.

So, even if it feels a bit scary to talk about our mental health, it's a really brave thing to do. It helps us take better care of ourselves and each other.

Your Ghibli-Style AI Image Just Burned More Energy Than Your Fridge. Still Worth It?

That cute, dreamy AI-generated image? It looks harmless. But behind the scenes, it’s an energy-hungry beast, devouring electricity and overheating servers across the world.

And you’re not alone - millions of people are generating AI art daily, without realizing that this innocent trend is quietly fueling climate change.

The Harsh Reality of AI Art:

- One high-quality AI image consumes as much energy as charging your phone 50 times.

- A single AI model like Midjourney or Stable Diffusion requires *thousands of GPUs*, each consuming 250-400 watts per hour - that’s like running a fridge non-stop.

- Data centers powering AI art use 200 terawatt-hours per year - more than some small countries!

- These centers require massive cooling systems, wasting *millions of gallons of water* just to keep the machines from melting.

We’re literally burning the planet for pretty pictures.

Think about it: AI-generated art is fun, but is it worth overheating the Earth for a few likes on Instagram?

We don’t see the carbon emissions. We don’t see the energy drain. But every time we hit “generate,” we’re pushing the world closer to a climate disaster.

Maybe it’s time we stop using AI just for fun and start thinking about the real cost.
